data.wave_or_subset: ESS rounds 1–4 (2002–2009); excludes newer democracies in Central and Eastern Europe; excludes non-citizens and minorities
data.notes: Non-citizens and minorities excluded (5,101 observations; ~4% of total). Political distrust measured on 0–10 scales for trust in parliament, legal system, and politicians, reverse-coded to indicate distrust. Concern about immigration index constructed by reversing and averaging items on economic, cultural, and overall living conditions (Cronbach’s alpha = 0.83). Additional indices and items use reversed coding; another three-item index reported alpha = 0.76. Country-level variables include far-right party popularity and social protection expenditures; historical-level variable indicates long-term immigration-country status; governance quality index based on World Bank indicators. Economic context includes GDP per capita and unemployment.

method.description: The study uses multilevel (hierarchical linear) modeling of ESS 2002–2009 data to assess how concern about immigration relates to political distrust in national institutions, accounting for individual-, country-round-, and country-level factors. An instrumental variables analysis on ESS Round 1 addresses potential endogeneity of immigration concern.
steps: Restrict sample to citizens and non-minority respondents; exclude newer democracies in Central and Eastern Europe.
Construct outcome measures: reverse-code 0–10 trust in parliament, politicians, and legal system to form distrust indices.
Construct immigration concern index by reversing and averaging items on economic impact, cultural impact, and overall living conditions of immigration (check reliability; alpha reported as 0.83).

Assemble individual-level controls: dissatisfaction with national economy, household income situation, health and education systems; interpersonal distrust; winner/loser of last election; left–right self-placement; household income; age; education; gender; vote for far-right party.
Assemble country-round variables: far-right party popularity (vote share), social protection expenditure per capita; economic indicators (e.g., GDP per capita, unemployment).
Assemble country-level (historical) variables: long-term immigration-country indicator; governance quality index from World Bank indicators.
Fit three-level hierarchical linear models predicting distrust in parliament, politicians, and legal system from immigration concern and controls.
Estimate interaction effects between immigration concern and long-term immigration-country status, and between immigration concern and far-right party popularity.
Conduct instrumental variables analysis on ESS Round 1 to test for endogeneity of immigration concern with respect to political distrust.
Evaluate variance components at individual, country-round, and country levels; assess robustness and significance.
method.models: Hierarchical Linear Modeling (multilevel, three-level HLM); Instrumental Variables analysis (ESS Round 1)
method.outcome_variable: Political distrust in national institutions: reverse-coded 0–10 measures of trust in parliament, politicians, and the legal system
method.independent_variables: Concern about immigration index (reverse-coded, 0–10); interactions with long-term immigration-country status and with far-right party popularity
method.control_variables: Dissatisfaction with national economy; dissatisfaction with household income; dissatisfaction with health services and education system; interpersonal distrust; vote for far-right party in last general election; winner/loser of last election; left–right self-placement; household income; age; education; gender; country-level social protection expenditure; GDP per capita; unemployment rate; governance quality

results.summary: Concern about immigration is a consistent, statistically significant predictor of political distrust in national institutions across Europe, even after extensive controls. Effects are stronger in countries with long post–World War II immigration histories. Interactions with far-right party popularity show amplification of the immigration concern–distrust relationship where far-right presence is notable, though the overall mobilizing effect of far-right parties is limited. Economic dissatisfaction and perceptions of poor institutional performance also increase political distrust, while higher social protection expenditure reduces it. Most variance resides at the individual level.
